Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Perennial Wetland Formation and Human Adaptation in NW Belize

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Tropical wetlands are important ecosystems with complex interactions between their soils and water, but little is known about how humans further affect and alter them over long time periods. This project will study northern Belize's wetlands to test models of wetland formation and long-term human-environmental interactions in the Maya Lowlands. Most previous Maya research has focused on risks such as recurrent droughts but rising water tables and water quality may prove to be comparable but insidious risks. This is a case of humans forced to adapt to rising water tables of extremely hard water. The main goals of this project are to determine the timing and processes of perennial wetland formation across a range of environments in the northern Belize coastal plain; to discern the underestimated role of water chemistry in landscape formation in this tropical region; and to establish the types and ranges of human adaptations to wetland formation, linking sites of previous research, including Blue Creek and Pulltrouser Swamp. The underlying questions come from both natural and social science. The project is testing six possible hypotheses to explain large-scale landscape aggradation and formation during the Holocene across the Belize coastal plain. This project will test the landscape development models by studying seven known ancient Maya wetland field sites that span from the Blue Creek research sites, through a zone that received no previous research on stratigraphy and dating, to the zone of research done several decades ago. This project will test these models with multidisciplinary research at two scales: intensive excavation across canals and fields and extensive vibracoring to determine wetland field extents. In each site, the project will study the lines of evidence that explain landscape formation and human interaction: stratigraphy, dating methods, soil morphology, sediment chemistry, ecofacts (pollen, diatoms), and artifacts. This project will also conduct water chemical analysis across this zone because of its key role in wetlands and its little-understood role in Maya Civilization.

This study will provide a case of an important Pre-Columbian society's land use responses in the face of natural sea level and water table rise; it will help flesh out the mechanisms of landscape formation over a little understood, large tropical wetland region; and it will help determine the Holocene rates and processes of tropical wetland formation when these bio-diverse regions again face sea level rise and other widespread threats. The study also provides basic soil and water chemistry data to a developing region, and these baseline parameters can help scientists and resource managers judge many aspects of environmental change such as wetland ecosystem functions. This project will provide graduate and undergraduate students experience in international field science and laboratory research. The project will include and train many from local communities during and between the field seasons. The project will disseminate findings on wetland formation and Maya cultural ecology to international conferences, peer reviewed journals, to students, and more widely through websites and the mass media. The infrastructure of science will be improved through both the multidisciplinary approach and the international nature of this research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project has focused on the history and development of the wetlands of the Maya Lowlands in northwestern Belize, studying land and water use history linked to ancient Maya occupation of the region. This project began as a collaborative grant shared by PIs formerly at George Mason and Georgetown Universities in 2009 (NSF 0924501, 0924510) The remaining project portion was transferred to the University of Texas at Austin in 2014, where both PIs moved. Field and laboratory research continued through summer 2016. This project has produced new knowledge and new data about the environment and Maya archaeology in Northwestern Belize, collaborating with The Programme for Belize Archaeological Project, the Maya Research Program, and a University of Puerto Rico Maya Forest Ecology project (NSF 1114947).

Intellectual Merit: Our project has confirmed hypotheses and provided new information about ancient Maya interactions with the landscape and specifically wetland resources. Our hydrology, soils, and geoarchaeological field and laboratory research revealed that aggradation (sediment accumulation) in the Chan Cahal wetlands occurred after the Maya initially farmed it as a stable soil surface. Our geochemical analyses demonstrated that the sedimentation source turned out to not be exclusively erosion from the uplands, but also mineral precipitation from another source: groundwater. As groundwater tables were driven up by sea level rise in the Belize coastal plain in the late Classic Maya period, gypsum (CaSO4.2H2O) precipitated out of saturated groundwater and accumulated, burying the stable soil surface. Our findings indicate the ancient Maya farmed both the ancient soil surface below and the wetland fields above through multiple lines of evidence, including chemical (e.g., carbon isotope ratios linked to distinct long-term signatures of corn vs. forest cover), physical (magnetic susceptibility), radiocarbon and AMS dating (carbon), archaeological remains (pottery sherds, stone tools, structural remains), and organic proxies (pollen, phytoliths, faunal, charcoal, and macrobotanical remains). The ancient Maya met this environmental change challenge by adapting the landscape for wetland field agriculture, by digging ditches to drain the land and control the seasonal flooding from the early Rio Bravo, demonstrating human resilience in the face of major environmental challenges that we can apply today in other coastal zones facing inundation.  Environmental challenges include a variable (seasonal) water supply and quality throughout the region, adding complexity to Maya water use and agriculture. These were challenges the Maya overcame with hydrologic engineering such as well digging and reservoir building. Tropical seasonal rains also bring complex management challenges to farmers, such as conserving soils from erosion, and the ancient Maya adapted landscapes in the uplands portion of this region by building agricultural terraces, some of which our latest, remote sensing acquisition reveals for the first time.

This work occurs in several dimensions, including horizontal to understand the extent of wetland agriculture, vertical to examine the geological or sedimentary history, and from above, using aerial imagery to map the three dimensions of these lands, x, y, and z extents, and shapes of natural and anthropogenic features. Many wetland field complexes, “agricultural geoglyphs”, are extensive enough that aerial is superior to ground level imaging. These wetland fields are impressive earth works in their own right created by humans with rudimentary tools and sophisticated mathematics, spatial thinking and engineering.  Our early aerial explorations included traditional aerial photography from airplanes, and progressed to acquiring and analyzing commercial imagery such as Spot, Landsat, and GeoEye. The purpose of remote sensing (and field checking) was to map and measure known fields and to detect suspected wetland fields, canals, and other features hidden below forest canopies. Our final phase of remote sensing in 2016 deployed airborne laser mapping, or LiDAR (Light Detection and Ranging). We acquired LiDAR images through this grant and a consortium of other researchers, including funds from UT-Austin, University of Puerto Rico (NSF 1114947), the Programme for Belize Archaeological Project (UT-Austin), and the Maya Research Program (UT-Tyler). We obtained a 250 km2 area of never before mapped LiDAR imagery over our study sites in NW Belize. The operation was a success, and the mapping center (NSF-funded National Center for Airborne Laser Mapping) just delivered the processed imagery to our research team on 23 November 2016. We are downloading it to analyze what we can about archaeological, hydrological, forest canopy, and geomorphic features.  An imagery preview revealed, and demonstrated, that LiDAR technology can detect wetland fields and canals hidden by jungle canopy.

Broader Impacts: The LiDAR preview phase demonstrated there is a much larger extent of wetland field complexes in Northwestern Belize than previously observed. This means that wetland field agriculture is not just small-scale, specialized farming as some viewed it before, but a major source of ancient Maya sustenance, lending new dimensions to Ancient Maya economics and sustainability, and potential modern analogs. We will report on this in forthcoming conferences, publications, theses, and dissertations, after formal spatial data analysis.
